body:
You can enable grpc tracing with
`export GRPC_TRACE=all && ./greeter_server` and same thing for the client.

I'm seeing the same "unknown compression level" error with our Haskell gRPC library (which uses the C core), on OS X with 0.15.0, when running a simple unary request/response test. Note this happens regardless of whether I set a compression level explicitly when starting the server. This didn't happen with 0.14.0, and is blocking us from upgrading to 0.15.0. 

Server trace:

```

```

Client trace:

```
D0728 13:21:30.534631000 140735123824640 ev_posix.c:101] Using polling engine: poll
E0728 13:21:31.123614000 123145307131904 chttp2_transport.c:1810] close_transport: {"created":"@1469737291.123526000","description":"Failed parsing HTTP/2","file":"src/core/ext/transport/chttp2/transport/chttp2_transport.c","file_line":1726,"referenced_errors":[{"created":"@1469737291.123515000","description":"EOF","file":"src/core/lib/iomgr/tcp_posix.c","file_line":233}]}
```

The error on the client side makes it look like this might be the same underlying issue as https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/7278.
@crclark , thanks. I'm having a look today. I seem to recall that this has been fixed on the pre-1.0.0. Would you mind testing against the "v1.0.x" branch? (or current HEAD, for that matter...)
Sure, I'll try to test against that branch and get back to you.
OTOH, `GRPC_TRACE` should be working as usual... I'll get back to you on that one.

@dgquintas Thanks for the quick reply. Unfortunately, I just rebuilt the library (v1.0.x) with the fix you suggested, and I'm still getting the same "unknown compression level" error. Let me know if you want me to try anything else.
@crclark `make install` as well? Perhaps the binary is picking up the old library file.

@dgquintas I added a printf under the changed line to make sure it's using my changed version. However, I just discovered that if I run the executable with valgrind, I don't get the error, so something strange might be going on. I'll keep digging.

BTW, a new environment variable `GRPC_VERBOSITY` was added in https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/7494 in order to control the amount of logging output. In order to get the former tracing behavior, one would have to do `GRPC_VERBOSITY=DEBUG GRPC_TRACE=all ...`

Some updates:
1. My previous comment still stands. The variable should be initialized. However, the problem wasn't there (its usage was always protected by `level_set`). The problem is actually [here](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/release-0_15/include/grpc++/impl/codegen/call.h#L183). There needs to be a `maybe_compression_level_.is_set = false` in that default constructor. The reasons are somewhat involved, but they add up to there being a new way to set compression options via initial metadata as opposed to C++ cheating and (over)reaching into the C core.
2. There has been [a pending PR](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/7502) with this and other changes (that fix the aforementioned C++ cheating). That's why all this seemed familiar. I'm merging it to master and backporting it to the v1.0.x branch today. I'd recommend picking up those changes, as it fixes everything The Right Way.

@dgquintas Would the fixes in https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/7502 help our library, which is only using the C library? I find it puzzling that this error occurs regardless of whether we set compression level in the grpc_channel_args.

@crclark hmm no, all I've been saying assumed C++. It's very surprising It happens when using only the C layer. Is there any way for me to repro? We run tests under msan for C, which should catch issues like this (which clearly look like an uninitialized variable issue).

@crclark hold on... here's where the issue may be. If you are dealing with the core directly, I assume you are assembling `grpc_op`s yourself, something like what happens [here](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/test/core/end2end/tests/large_metadata.c#L145). If so, you have to _always_ memset your ops to zero. Otherwise, in this particular case, `op->data.send_initial_metadata.maybe_compression_level.is_set` can have a non-zero value, which would then cause `op->data.send_initial_metadata.maybe_compression_level.level` to be taken into account while it also contains uninitialized garbage`.
@yookyoung89 could you pull from master (now that #7502 has been merged) and try again? Thanks!

@dgquintas Aha! We had initially modeled our code off those tests, but I hadn't thought to look for changes to the tests in 0.15 when tracking down the problem. That fixed it for me. Sorry if I led you astray!

@crclark no worries! In fact we found the bad form of the initialized variable and it reminded me to merge and backport to v1.0.x the critical C++ fix mentioned (which I'm sure does explain the rest of the similar bug reports).
Marking as fixed.

philips@z420:~/software/grpc/examples/cpp/helloworld$ ./greeter_server 
I0328 14:11:34.874821922     458 server_builder.cc:247]      Synchronous server. Num CQs: 1, Min pollers: 1, Max Pollers: 2147483647, CQ timeout (msec): 1000
Server listening on 0.0.0.0:50051


The problem is still there:


philips@z420:~/software/grpc/examples/cpp/helloworld$ ./greeter_client 
14: Connect Failed
Greeter received: RPC failed


The following is my installation script:

git clone -b $(curl -L http://grpc.io/release) https://github.com/grpc/grpc
cd grpc
git submodule update --init
make -j$(nproc)
sudo make -j$(nproc) install

Please specify:
- what version of gRPC you have installed
- what OS you are running on

Also please run with GRPC_VERBOSITY=DEBUG and GRPC_TRACE=all and paste the output

Me too
V1.4.3    && ubuntu 14.04

https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/9989

unset http_proxy

Yes you can use:
unset http_proxy
unset https_proxy
unset ftp_proxy
unset socks_proxy


But now it seem just work for me in the first several times , then when I use client to call server, it stuck. Not thing is showed and no "ask me failed" 
When I use :
ps aux | grep path/to/server or path/toclient

I saw that although I ctrl + z server or client already but They are not dead.
So I have to use : 

kill -9 

It work. But it is hard working.And I don't know how to get better way.
